name: Shelley v. Kraemer
first_party: J. D. Shelley and Ethel Lee Shelley et al.
facts_of_the_case: The Kraemers were a white couple who owned a residence in a Missouri neighborhood governed by a restrictive covenant. This was a private agreement that prevented blacks from owning property in the Kraemers' subdivision. The Shelleys were a black couple who moved into the Kraemers neighborhood. The Kraemers went to court to enforce the restrictive covenant against the Shelleys.
question: Does the enforcement of a racially restrictive covenant violate the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment?
conclusion: State courts could not constitutionally prevent the sale of real property to blacks even if that property is covered by a racially restrictive covenant. Standing alone, racially restrictive covenants violate no rights. However, their enforcement by state court injunctions constitute state action in violation of the 14th Amendment.

advocates.advocate_description: Solicitor General, Department of Justice, as amicus curiae, by special leave of Court

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

advocates.advocate_description: for the respondents in No. 87 and the respondents in Nos. 290 and 291
for the respondents in No. 87 and the respondents in Nos. 290 and 291
for the petitioners in Nos. 290 and 291
for the petitioners in Nos. 290 and 291

decisions.description: Although restrictive covenants did not fall under constitutional protection, state enforcement of such covenants violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment

description: A case in which the Court ruled that enforcement of racially restrictive covenants were a violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
